questions.question_text:
You have three compartments: ProjectA, ProjectB, and ProjectC. For each compartment, there is an admin group set up: A-Admins, B-Admins, and C-Admins.
Each admin group has full access over their respective compartments as shown in the graphic below.
Your organization has set up a tag namespace, EmployeeGroup.Role and all your admin groups are tagged with a value of 'Admin'.
//IMG//

You want to set up a Test compartment for members of the three projects to share. You also need to provide admin access to all three of your existing admin groups.
Which policy would you write to accomplish this task?

choices.A: Allow dynamic-group to manage all-resources in compartment Test where request.principal.group.tag.EmployeeGroup.Role='Admin'
choices.C: Allow group any-group to manage all-resources in compartment Test where request.principal.group.tag.EmployeeGroup.Role='Admin'
choices.B: Allow all-group to manage all-resources in compartment Test where request.principal.group.tag.EmployeeGroup.Role='Admin'
choices.D: Allow any user to manage all resources in compartment Test where request.principal.group.tag.EmployeeGroup.Role='Admin'

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I think it is D. (although there seems to be typo)

Syntax:{{ group <group_name> | group id <group_ocid> | dynamic-group <dynamic-group_name> | dynamic-group id <dynamic-group_ocid>| any-group | any-user}}

https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Identity/Concepts/policysyntax.htm

Selected Answer: C
C. Allow group any-group to manage all-resources in compartment Test where request.principal.group.tag.EmployeeGroup.Role='Admin'

Explanation:

 The "C. Allow group any-group" part of the policy grants permissions to the group named "any-group."
 "to manage all-resources in compartment Test" specifies that this group has management permissions in the "Test" compartment.
 "where request.principal.group.tag.EmployeeGroup.Role='Admin'" ensures that only members of groups tagged with 'Admin' in the "EmployeeGroup.Role" namespace will have this access.

This policy allows any user who is a member of a group with the 'Admin' tag in the specified namespace to manage resources in the "Test" compartment.

choices.A: Cloning an existing volume to a new, larger volume.
choices.C: Restoring from a volume backup to a larger volume.
choices.D: Attaching a block volume to an instance in a different availability domain.
choices.B: Expanding an existing volume in place with offline resizing.

Selected Answer: D
D. Attaching a block volume to an instance in a different availability domain.

Attaching a block volume to an instance in a different availability domain is not a valid action within the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Block Volume service. Block volumes can typically be attached to instances within the same availability domain, but they cannot be attached across availability domains due to the isolation and redundancy boundaries between availability domains.

When you clone a volume in OCI, you have the flexibility to specify a different size for the clone if needed. This allows you to either create a clone with the same size as the source volume or resize the clone to a different size to meet your specific requirements.

The other statements are not accurate:

The other statements are not accurate:

B. You need to detach a volume before cloning it: Detaching a volume is not a requirement for cloning it. Cloning can be performed while the volume is still attached to an instance.

C. Creating a clone takes longer than creating a backup of a volume: Creating a clone of a volume typically takes less time than creating a backup. Cloning involves making a copy of the volume with its data, while creating a backup involves creating a separate backup object.

D. You can clone a volume to another region: Currently, volume cloning is limited to the same region in OCI. Cloning a volume to another region is not possible.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements is true about cloning a volume in the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Block Volume service?
Which TWO statements about the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) File Storage Service are accurate? (Choose two.)

choices.E: Communication with file systems in a mount target is encrypted via HTTPS.
choices.B: Mount targets use Oracle-managed keys by default.
choices.A: File systems use Oracle-managed keys by default.
choices.D: Customer can encrypt data in their file system using their own Vault encryption key.
choices.C: Customer can encrypt the communication to a mount target via export options.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
B, C, E are incorrect because, mount targets do not use encryption by default. You must explicitly enable encryption for mount targets. You can do this using the OCI Console, the OCI CLI, or the OCI API.

You cannot encrypt the communication to a mount target via export options. Export options are used to control how files are exported from a file system to a mount target. They do not support encryption.

Communication with file systems in a mount target is encrypted using TLS. TLS is a cryptographic protocol that provides secure communication over a computer network.
A and D

Selected Answer: AD
By default all file systems are encrypted using Oracle-managed encryption keys. You have the option to encrypt all of your file systems using the keys that you own and manage using the Vault service. 

https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/File/Concepts/filestorageoverview.htm
